.+.description: Custom field not present in the schema.

@timestamp.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

Date/time when the event originated.
This is the date/time extracted from the event, typically representing when the event was generated by the source.
If the event source has no original timestamp, this value is typically populated by the first time the event was received by the pipeline.
Required field for all events.

agent.build.original.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Extended build information for the agent.
This field is intended to contain any build information that a data source may provide, no specific formatting is required.

agent.ephemeral_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Ephemeral identifier of this agent (if one exists).
This id normally changes across restarts, but `agent.id` does not.

agent.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Unique identifier of this agent (if one exists).
Example: For Beats this would be beat.id.

agent.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Custom name of the agent.
This is a name that can be given to an agent. This can be helpful if for example two Filebeat instances are running on the same host but a human readable separation is needed on which Filebeat instance data is coming from.

agent.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Type of the agent.
The agent type always stays the same and should be given by the agent used. In case of Filebeat the agent would always be Filebeat also if two Filebeat instances are run on the same machine.

agent.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Version of the agent.

client.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Some event client addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.

Organization name.

client.bytes.description:
Module: ecs

Array: False

Bytes sent from the client to the server.

client.domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The domain name of the client system.
This value may be a host name, a fully qualified domain name, or another host naming format. The value may derive from the original event or be added from enrichment.

client.geo.city_name.description:
Module: ecs

Array: False

City name.

client.geo.continent_code.description:

Not typically used in automated geolocation.

client.geo.postal_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Postal code associated with the location.

client.geo.region_iso_code.description:

Region ISO code.

client.geo.region_name.description:

client.ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip
Array: False

IP address of the client (IPv4 or IPv6).

client.mac.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

MAC address of the client.
The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

client.nat.ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip
Array: False

Translated IP of source based NAT sessions (e.g. internal client to internet).
Typically connections traversing load balancers, firewalls, or routers.

client.nat.port.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Translated port of source based NAT sessions (e.g. internal client to internet).
Typically connections traversing load balancers, firewalls, or routers.

client.packets.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Packets sent from the client to the server.

client.port.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Port of the client.

client.registered_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The highest registered client domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

client.subdomain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The subdomain portion of a fully qualified domain name includes all of the names except the host name under the registered_domain.  In a partially qualified domain, or if the the qualification level of the full name cannot be determined, subdomain contains all of the names below the registered domain.
For example the subdomain portion of "www.east.mydomain.co.uk" is "east". If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.

client.top_level_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

client.user.domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Name of the directory the user is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

Array: False

User email address.

client.user.group.domain.description:

Name of the group.

data_stream.dataset.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The field can contain anything that makes sense to signify the source of the data.
Examples include `nginx.access`, `prometheus`, `endpoint` etc. For data streams that otherwise fit, but that do not have dataset set we use the value "generic" for the dataset value. `event.dataset` should have the same value as `data_stream.dataset`.
Beyond the Elasticsearch data stream naming criteria noted above, the `dataset` value has additional restrictions:
  * Must not contain `-`
  * No longer than 100 characters

data_stream.namespace.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

A user defined namespace. Namespaces are useful to allow grouping of data.
Many users already organize their indices this way, and the data stream naming scheme now provides this best practice as a default. Many users will populate this field with `default`. If no value is used, it falls back to `default`.
Beyond the Elasticsearch index naming criteria noted above, `namespace` value has the additional restrictions:
  * Must not contain `-`
  * No longer than 100 characters

data_stream.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

An overarching type for the data stream.
Currently allowed values are "logs" and "metrics". We expect to also add "traces" and "synthetics" in the near future.

destination.registered_domain.description:

In a partially qualified domain, or if the the qualification level of the full name cannot be determined, subdomain contains all of the names below the registered domain.
For example the subdomain portion of "www.east.mydomain.co.uk" is "east". If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.

device.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The unique identifier of a device. The identifier must not change across application sessions but stay fixed for an instance of a (mobile) device. 
On iOS, this value must be equal to the vendor identifier (https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uidevice/1620059-identifierforvendor). On Android, this value must be equal to the Firebase Installation ID or a globally unique UUID which is persisted across sessions in your application.
For GDPR and data protection law reasons this identifier should not carry information that would allow to identify a user.

dll.code_signature.team_id.description:

dll.code_signature.timestamp.description:

dll.code_signature.trusted.description:

Array: False

Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

dll.code_signature.valid.description:

dll.hash.tlsh.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

TLSH hash.

dll.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Name of the library.
This generally maps to the name of the file on disk.

dll.path.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Full file path of the library.

dll.pe.architecture.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

CPU architecture target for the file.

dll.pe.company.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Internal company name of the file, provided at compile-time.

dll.pe.description.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Internal description of the file, provided at compile-time.

dll.pe.file_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Internal version of the file, provided at compile-time.

dll.pe.go_import_hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

A hash of the Go language imports in a PE file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available [here](https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma).

dll.pe.go_imports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object
Array: False

List of imported Go language element names and types.

dll.pe.go_imports_names_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

dll.pe.go_imports_names_var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

dll.pe.go_stripped.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

Set to true if the file is a Go executable that has had its symbols stripped or obfuscated and false if an unobfuscated Go executable.

dll.pe.imphash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

A hash of the imports in a PE file. An imphash -- or import hash -- can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
Learn more at https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2014/01/tracking-malware-import-hashing.html.

dll.pe.import_hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

A hash of the imports in a PE file. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
This is a synonym for imphash.

dll.pe.imports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object
Array: True

List of imported element names and types.

dll.pe.imports_names_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

dll.pe.imports_names_var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

dll.pe.original_file_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Internal name of the file, provided at compile-time.

dll.pe.pehash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

A hash of the PE header and data from one or more PE sections. An pehash can be used to cluster files by transforming structural information about a file into a hash value.
Learn more at https://www.usenix.org/legacy/events/leet09/tech/full_papers/wicherski/wicherski_html/index.html.

dll.pe.product.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Internal product name of the file, provided at compile-time.

dll.pe.sections.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: nested
Array: True

An array containing an object for each section of the PE file.
The keys that should be present in these objects are defined by sub-fields underneath `pe.sections.*`.

entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

PE Section List name.

physical_size.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

PE Section List physical size.

var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

virtual_size.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

PE Section List virtual size. This is always the same as `physical_size`.

dns.answers.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object
Array: True

An array containing an object for each answer section returned by the server.
The main keys that should be present in these objects are defined by ECS. Records that have more information may contain more keys than what ECS defines.
Not all DNS data sources give all details about DNS answers. At minimum, answer objects must contain the `data` key. If more information is available, map as much of it to ECS as possible, and add any additional fields to the answer objects as custom fields.

class.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The class of DNS data contained in this resource record.

data.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The data describing the resource.
The meaning of this data depends on the type and class of the resource record.

name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The domain name to which this resource record pertains.
If a chain of CNAME is being resolved, each answer's `name` should be the one that corresponds with the answer's `data`. It should not simply be the original `question.name` repeated.

ttl.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

The time interval in seconds that this resource record may be cached before it should be discarded. Zero values mean that the data should not be cached.

type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The type of data contained in this resource record.

dns.header_flags.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

Array of 2 letter DNS header flags.

dns.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The DNS packet identifier assigned by the program that generated the query. The identifier is copied to the response.

dns.op_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The DNS operation code that specifies the kind of query in the message. This value is set by the originator of a query and copied into the response.

dns.question.class.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The class of records being queried.

dns.question.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The name being queried.
If the name field contains non-printable characters (below 32 or above 126), those characters should be represented as escaped base 10 integers (\DDD). Back slashes and quotes should be escaped. Tabs, carriage returns, and line feeds should be converted to \t, \r, and \n respectively.

dns.question.registered_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The highest registered domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

dns.question.subdomain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The subdomain is all of the labels under the registered_domain.
If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.

dns.question.top_level_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

dns.question.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The type of record being queried.

dns.resolved_ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip
Array: True

Array containing all IPs seen in `answers.data`.
The `answers` array can be difficult to use, because of the variety of data formats it can contain. Extracting all IP addresses seen in there to `dns.resolved_ip` makes it possible to index them as IP addresses, and makes them easier to visualize and query for.

dns.response_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The DNS response code.

dns.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The type of DNS event captured, query or answer.
If your source of DNS events only gives you DNS queries, you should only create dns events of type `dns.type:query`.
If your source of DNS events gives you answers as well, you should create one event per query (optionally as soon as the query is seen). And a second event containing all query details as well as an array of answers.

ecs.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

ECS version this event conforms to. `ecs.version` is a required field and must exist in all events.
When querying across multiple indices -- which may conform to slightly different ECS versions -- this field lets integrations adjust to the schema version of the events.

email.attachments.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: nested
Array: True

A list of objects describing the attachment files sent along with an email message.

file.extension.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Attachment file extension, excluding the leading dot.

file.hash.md5.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

MD5 hash.

file.hash.sha1.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

SHA1 hash.

file.hash.sha256.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

SHA256 hash.

file.hash.sha384.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

SHA384 hash.

file.hash.sha512.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

SHA512 hash.

file.hash.ssdeep.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

SSDEEP hash.

file.hash.tlsh.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

TLSH hash.

file.mime_type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The MIME media type of the attachment.
This value will typically be extracted from the `Content-Type` MIME header field.

file.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Name of the attachment file including the file extension.

file.size.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Attachment file size in bytes.

email.bcc.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

The email address of BCC recipient

email.cc.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

The email address of CC recipient

email.content_type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Information about how the message is to be displayed.
Typically a MIME type.

email.delivery_timestamp.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

The date and time when the email message was received by the service or client.

email.direction.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The direction of the message based on the sending and receiving domains.

email.from.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

The email address of the sender, typically from the RFC 5322 `From:` header field.

email.local_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Unique identifier given to the email by the source that created the event.
Identifier is not persistent across hops.

email.message_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: wildcard
Array: False

Identifier from the RFC 5322 `Message-ID:` email header that refers to a particular email message.

email.origination_timestamp.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

The date and time the email message was composed. Many email clients will fill in this value automatically when the message is sent by a user.

email.reply_to.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

The address that replies should be delivered to based on the value in the RFC 5322 `Reply-To:` header.

email.sender.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Per RFC 5322, specifies the address responsible for the actual transmission of the message.

email.subject.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

A brief summary of the topic of the message.

email.to.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

The email address of recipient

email.x_mailer.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The name of the application that was used to draft and send the original email message.

error.code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Error code describing the error.

error.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Unique identifier for the error.

error.message.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: text
Array: False

Error message.

error.stack_trace.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: wildcard
Array: False

The stack trace of this error in plain text.

error.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The type of the error, for example the class name of the exception.

event.action.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The action captured by the event.
This describes the information in the event. It is more specific than `event.category`. Examples are `group-add`, `process-started`, `file-created`. The value is normally defined by the implementer.

event.agent_id_status.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Agents are normally responsible for populating the `agent.id` field value. If the system receiving events is capable of validating the value based on authentication information for the client then this field can be used to reflect the outcome of that validation.
For example if the agent's connection is authenticated with mTLS and the client cert contains the ID of the agent to which the cert was issued then the `agent.id` value in events can be checked against the certificate. If the values match then `event.agent_id_status: verified` is added to the event, otherwise one of the other allowed values should be used.
If no validation is performed then the field should be omitted.
The allowed values are:
`verified` - The `agent.id` field value matches expected value obtained from auth metadata.
`mismatch` - The `agent.id` field value does not match the expected value obtained from auth metadata.
`missing` - There was no `agent.id` field in the event to validate.
`auth_metadata_missing` - There was no auth metadata or it was missing information about the agent ID.

event.category.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the second level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.category` represents the "big buckets" of ECS categories. For example, filtering on `event.category:process` yields all events relating to process activity. This field is closely related to `event.type`, which is used as a subcategory.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple categories.

event.code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Identification code for this event, if one exists.
Some event sources use event codes to identify messages unambiguously, regardless of message language or wording adjustments over time. An example of this is the Windows Event ID.

event.created.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

`event.created` contains the date/time when the event was first read by an agent, or by your pipeline.
This field is distinct from `@timestamp` in that `@timestamp` typically contain the time extracted from the original event.
In most situations, these two timestamps will be slightly different. The difference can be used to calculate the delay between your source generating an event, and the time when your agent first processed it. This can be used to monitor your agent's or pipeline's ability to keep up with your event source.
In case the two timestamps are identical, `@timestamp` should be used.

event.dataset.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Name of the dataset.
If an event source publishes more than one type of log or events (e.g. access log, error log), the dataset is used to specify which one the event comes from.
It's recommended but not required to start the dataset name with the module name, followed by a dot, then the dataset name.

event.duration.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Duration of the event in nanoseconds.
If `event.start` and `event.end` are known this value should be the difference between the end and start time.

event.end.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

`event.end` contains the date when the event ended or when the activity was last observed.

event.hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Hash (perhaps logstash fingerprint) of raw field to be able to demonstrate log integrity.

event.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Unique ID to describe the event.

event.ingested.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

Timestamp when an event arrived in the central data store.
This is different from `@timestamp`, which is when the event originally occurred.  It's also different from `event.created`, which is meant to capture the first time an agent saw the event.
In normal conditions, assuming no tampering, the timestamps should chronologically look like this: `@timestamp` < `event.created` < `event.ingested`.

event.kind.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the highest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.kind` gives high-level information about what type of information the event contains, without being specific to the contents of the event. For example, values of this field distinguish alert events from metric events.
The value of this field can be used to inform how these kinds of events should be handled. They may warrant different retention, different access control, it may also help understand whether the data is coming in at a regular interval or not.

event.module.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Name of the module this data is coming from.
If your monitoring agent supports the concept of modules or plugins to process events of a given source (e.g. Apache logs), `event.module` should contain the name of this module.

event.original.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Raw text message of entire event. Used to demonstrate log integrity or where the full log message (before splitting it up in multiple parts) may be required, e.g. for reindex.
This field is not indexed and doc_values are disabled. It cannot be searched, but it can be retrieved from `_source`. If users wish to override this and index this field, please see `Field data types` in the `Elasticsearch Reference`.

event.outcome.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the lowest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.outcome` simply denotes whether the event represents a success or a failure from the perspective of the entity that produced the event.
Note that when a single transaction is described in multiple events, each event may populate different values of `event.outcome`, according to their perspective.
Also note that in the case of a compound event (a single event that contains multiple logical events), this field should be populated with the value that best captures the overall success or failure from the perspective of the event producer.
Further note that not all events will have an associated outcome. For example, this field is generally not populated for metric events, events with `event.type:info`, or any events for which an outcome does not make logical sense.

event.provider.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Source of the event.
Event transports such as Syslog or the Windows Event Log typically mention the source of an event. It can be the name of the software that generated the event (e.g. Sysmon, httpd), or of a subsystem of the operating system (kernel, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing).

event.reason.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Reason why this event happened, according to the source.
This describes the why of a particular action or outcome captured in the event. Where `event.action` captures the action from the event, `event.reason` describes why that action was taken. For example, a web proxy with an `event.action` which denied the request may also populate `event.reason` with the reason why (e.g. `blocked site`).

event.reference.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Reference URL linking to additional information about this event.
This URL links to a static definition of this event. Alert events, indicated by `event.kind:alert`, are a common use case for this field.

event.risk_score.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: float
Array: False

Risk score or priority of the event (e.g. security solutions). Use your system's original value here.

event.risk_score_norm.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: float
Array: False

Normalized risk score or priority of the event, on a scale of 0 to 100.
This is mainly useful if you use more than one system that assigns risk scores, and you want to see a normalized value across all systems.

event.sequence.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Sequence number of the event.
The sequence number is a value published by some event sources, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regardless of the timestamp precision.

event.severity.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

The numeric severity of the event according to your event source.
What the different severity values mean can be different between sources and use cases. It's up to the implementer to make sure severities are consistent across events from the same source.
The Syslog severity belongs in `log.syslog.severity.code`. `event.severity` is meant to represent the severity according to the event source (e.g. firewall, IDS). If the event source does not publish its own severity, you may optionally copy the `log.syslog.severity.code` to `event.severity`.

event.start.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

`event.start` contains the date when the event started or when the activity was first observed.

event.timezone.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

This field should be populated when the event's timestamp does not include timezone information already (e.g. default Syslog timestamps). It's optional otherwise.
Acceptable timezone formats are: a canonical ID (e.g. "Europe/Amsterdam"), abbreviated (e.g. "EST") or an HH:mm differential (e.g. "-05:00").

event.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the third level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.type` represents a categorization "sub-bucket" that, when used along with the `event.category` field values, enables filtering events down to a level appropriate for single visualization.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple event types.

event.url.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

URL linking to an external system to continue investigation of this event.
This URL links to another system where in-depth investigation of the specific occurrence of this event can take place. Alert events, indicated by `event.kind:alert`, are a common use case for this field.

faas.coldstart.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

Boolean value indicating a cold start of a function.

faas.execution.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The execution ID of the current function execution.

faas.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The unique identifier of a serverless function.
For AWS Lambda it's the function ARN (Amazon Resource Name) without a version or alias suffix.

faas.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The name of a serverless function.

faas.trigger.request_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The ID of the trigger request , message, event, etc.

faas.trigger.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The trigger for the function execution.

faas.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The version of a serverless function.

file.accessed.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

Last time the file was accessed.
Note that not all filesystems keep track of access time.

file.attributes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

Array of file attributes.
Attributes names will vary by platform. Here's a non-exhaustive list of values that are expected in this field: archive, compressed, directory, encrypted, execute, hidden, read, readonly, system, write.

file.code_signature.digest_algorithm.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The hashing algorithm used to sign the process.
This value can distinguish signatures when a file is signed multiple times by the same signer but with a different digest algorithm.

file.code_signature.exists.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

file.code_signature.signing_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

file.code_signature.status.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

file.code_signature.subject_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Subject name of the code signer

file.code_signature.team_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

file.code_signature.timestamp.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

Date and time when the code signature was generated and signed.

file.code_signature.trusted.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

file.code_signature.valid.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

file.created.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

File creation time.
Note that not all filesystems store the creation time.

file.ctime.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

Last time the file attributes or metadata changed.
Note that changes to the file content will update `mtime`. This implies `ctime` will be adjusted at the same time, since `mtime` is an attribute of the file.

file.device.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Device that is the source of the file.

file.directory.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Directory where the file is located. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

file.drive_letter.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Drive letter where the file is located. This field is only relevant on Windows.
The value should be uppercase, and not include the colon.

file.elf.architecture.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Machine architecture of the ELF file.

file.elf.byte_order.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Byte sequence of ELF file.

file.elf.cpu_type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

CPU type of the ELF file.

file.elf.creation_date.description:

file.fork_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

A fork is additional data associated with a filesystem object.
On Linux, a resource fork is used to store additional data with a filesystem object. A file always has at least one fork for the data portion, and additional forks may exist.
On NTFS, this is analogous to an Alternate Data Stream (ADS), and the default data stream for a file is just called $DATA. Zone.Identifier is commonly used by Windows to track contents downloaded from the Internet. An ADS is typically of the form: `C:\path\to\filename.extension:some_fork_name`, and `some_fork_name` is the value that should populate `fork_name`. `filename.extension` should populate `file.name`, and `extension` should populate `file.extension`. The full path, `file.path`, will include the fork name.

IndexerType: float
Array: False

A risk classification score calculated by an internal system as part of entity analytics and entity risk scoring.

host.risk.calculated_score_norm.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: float
Array: False

A risk classification score calculated by an internal system as part of entity analytics and entity risk scoring, and normalized to a range of 0 to 100.

host.risk.static_level.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

A risk classification level obtained from outside the system, such as from some external Threat Intelligence Platform.

host.risk.static_score.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: float
Array: False

A risk classification score obtained from outside the system, such as from some external Threat Intelligence Platform.

host.risk.static_score_norm.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: float
Array: False

A risk classification score obtained from outside the system, such as from some external Threat Intelligence Platform, and normalized to a range of 0 to 100.

host.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Type of host.
For Cloud providers this can be the machine type like `t2.medium`. If vm, this could be the container, for example, or other information meaningful in your environment.

host.uptime.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Seconds the host has been up.

http.request.body.bytes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Size in bytes of the request body.

http.request.body.content.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: wildcard
Array: False

The full HTTP request body.

http.request.bytes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Total size in bytes of the request (body and headers).

http.request.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

A unique identifier for each HTTP request to correlate logs between clients and servers in transactions.
The id may be contained in a non-standard HTTP header, such as `X-Request-ID` or `X-Correlation-ID`.

http.request.method.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

HTTP request method.
The value should retain its casing from the original event. For example, `GET`, `get`, and `GeT` are all considered valid values for this field.

http.request.mime_type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Mime type of the body of the request.
This value must only be populated based on the content of the request body, not on the `Content-Type` header. Comparing the mime type of a request with the request's Content-Type header can be helpful in detecting threats or misconfigured clients.

http.request.referrer.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Referrer for this HTTP request.

http.response.body.bytes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Size in bytes of the response body.

http.response.body.content.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: wildcard
Array: False

The full HTTP response body.

http.response.bytes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Total size in bytes of the response (body and headers).

http.response.mime_type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Mime type of the body of the response.
This value must only be populated based on the content of the response body, not on the `Content-Type` header. Comparing the mime type of a response with the response's Content-Type header can be helpful in detecting misconfigured servers.

http.response.status_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

HTTP response status code.

http.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

HTTP version.

labels.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object
Array: False

Custom key/value pairs.
Can be used to add meta information to events. Should not contain nested objects. All values are stored as keyword.
Example: `docker` and `k8s` labels.

log.file.path.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Full path to the log file this event came from, including the file name. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.
If the event wasn't read from a log file, do not populate this field.

log.level.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Original log level of the log event.
If the source of the event provides a log level or textual severity, this is the one that goes in `log.level`. If your source doesn't specify one, you may put your event transport's severity here (e.g. Syslog severity).
Some examples are `warn`, `err`, `i`, `informational`.

log.logger.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The name of the logger inside an application. This is usually the name of the class which initialized the logger, or can be a custom name.

log.origin.file.line.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

The line number of the file containing the source code which originated the log event.

log.origin.file.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The name of the file containing the source code which originated the log event.
Note that this field is not meant to capture the log file. The correct field to capture the log file is `log.file.path`.

log.origin.function.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The name of the function or method which originated the log event.

log.syslog.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object
Array: False

The Syslog metadata of the event, if the event was transmitted via Syslog. Please see RFCs 5424 or 3164.

appname.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The device or application that originated the Syslog message, if available.

facility.code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

The Syslog numeric facility of the log event, if available.
According to RFCs 5424 and 3164, this value should be an integer between 0 and 23.

facility.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The Syslog text-based facility of the log event, if available.

hostname.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The hostname, FQDN, or IP of the machine that originally sent the Syslog message. This is sourced from the hostname field of the syslog header. Depending on the environment, this value may be different from the host that handled the event, especially if the host handling the events is acting as a collector.

msgid.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

An identifier for the type of Syslog message, if available. Only applicable for RFC 5424 messages.

priority.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Syslog numeric priority of the event, if available.
According to RFCs 5424 and 3164, the priority is 8 * facility + severity. This number is therefore expected to contain a value between 0 and 191.

procid.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The process name or ID that originated the Syslog message, if available.

severity.code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

The Syslog numeric severity of the log event, if available.
If the event source publishing via Syslog provides a different numeric severity value (e.g. firewall, IDS), your source's numeric severity should go to `event.severity`. If the event source does not specify a distinct severity, you can optionally copy the Syslog severity to `event.severity`.

severity.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The Syslog numeric severity of the log event, if available.
If the event source publishing via Syslog provides a different severity value (e.g. firewall, IDS), your source's text severity should go to `log.level`. If the event source does not specify a distinct severity, you can optionally copy the Syslog severity to `log.level`.

structured_data.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object
Array: False

Structured data expressed in RFC 5424 messages, if available. These are key-value pairs formed from the structured data portion of the syslog message, as defined in RFC 5424 Section 6.3.

version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The version of the Syslog protocol specification. Only applicable for RFC 5424 messages.

message.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: text
Array: False

For log events the message field contains the log message, optimized for viewing in a log viewer.
For structured logs without an original message field, other fields can be concatenated to form a human-readable summary of the event.
If multiple messages exist, they can be combined into one message.

network.application.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

When a specific application or service is identified from network connection details (source/dest IPs, ports, certificates, or wire format), this field captures the application's or service's name.
For example, the original event identifies the network connection being from a specific web service in a `https` network connection, like `facebook` or `twitter`.
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

network.bytes.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Total bytes transferred in both directions.
If `source.bytes` and `destination.bytes` are known, `network.bytes` is their sum.

network.community_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

A hash of source and destination IPs and ports, as well as the protocol used in a communication. This is a tool-agnostic standard to identify flows.
Learn more at https://github.com/corelight/community-id-spec.

network.direction.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Direction of the network traffic.
When mapping events from a host-based monitoring context, populate this field from the host's point of view, using the values "ingress" or "egress".
When mapping events from a network or perimeter-based monitoring context, populate this field from the point of view of the network perimeter, using the values "inbound", "outbound", "internal" or "external".
Note that "internal" is not crossing perimeter boundaries, and is meant to describe communication between two hosts within the perimeter. Note also that "external" is meant to describe traffic between two hosts that are external to the perimeter. This could for example be useful for ISPs or VPN service providers.

network.forwarded_ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip
Array: False

Host IP address when the source IP address is the proxy.

network.iana_number.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

IANA Protocol Number (https://www.iana.org/assignments/protocol-numbers/protocol-numbers.xhtml). Standardized list of protocols. This aligns well with NetFlow and sFlow related logs which use the IANA Protocol Number.

network.inner.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object
Array: False

Network.inner fields are added in addition to network.vlan fields to describe the innermost VLAN when q-in-q VLAN tagging is present. Allowed fields include vlan.id and vlan.name. Inner vlan fields are typically used when sending traffic with multiple 802.1q encapsulations to a network sensor (e.g. Zeek, Wireshark.)

vlan.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

VLAN ID as reported by the observer.

vlan.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Optional VLAN name as reported by the observer.

network.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Name given by operators to sections of their network.

network.packets.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Total packets transferred in both directions.
If `source.packets` and `destination.packets` are known, `network.packets` is their sum.

network.protocol.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

In the OSI Model this would be the Application Layer protocol. For example, `http`, `dns`, or `ssh`.
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

network.transport.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Same as network.iana_number, but instead using the Keyword name of the transport layer (udp, tcp, ipv6-icmp, etc.)
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

network.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

In the OSI Model this would be the Network Layer. ipv4, ipv6, ipsec, pim, etc
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

network.vlan.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

VLAN ID as reported by the observer.

network.vlan.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Optional VLAN name as reported by the observer.

observer.egress.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object
Array: False

Observer.egress holds information like interface number and name, vlan, and zone information to classify egress traffic.  Single armed monitoring such as a network sensor on a span port should only use observer.ingress to categorize traffic.

interface.alias.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Interface alias as reported by the system, typically used in firewall implementations for e.g. inside, outside, or dmz logical interface naming.

interface.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Interface ID as reported by an observer (typically SNMP interface ID).

interface.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Interface name as reported by the system.

vlan.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

VLAN ID as reported by the observer.

vlan.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Optional VLAN name as reported by the observer.

zone.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Network zone of outbound traffic as reported by the observer to categorize the destination area of egress traffic, e.g. Internal, External, DMZ, HR, Legal, etc.

observer.geo.city_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

City name.

observer.geo.continent_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Two-letter code representing continent's name.

observer.geo.continent_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Name of the continent.

observer.geo.country_iso_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Country ISO code.

observer.geo.country_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Country name.

observer.geo.location.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: geo_point
Array: False

Longitude and latitude.

observer.geo.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

observer.geo.postal_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

observer.geo.region_iso_code.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Region ISO code.

observer.geo.region_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Region name.

observer.geo.timezone.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

observer.hostname.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Hostname of the observer.

observer.ingress.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object
Array: False

Observer.ingress holds information like interface number and name, vlan, and zone information to classify ingress traffic.  Single armed monitoring such as a network sensor on a span port should only use observer.ingress to categorize traffic.

interface.alias.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Interface alias as reported by the system, typically used in firewall implementations for e.g. inside, outside, or dmz logical interface naming.

interface.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Interface ID as reported by an observer (typically SNMP interface ID).

interface.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Interface name as reported by the system.

vlan.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

VLAN ID as reported by the observer.

vlan.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Optional VLAN name as reported by the observer.

zone.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Network zone of incoming traffic as reported by the observer to categorize the source area of ingress traffic. e.g. internal, External, DMZ, HR, Legal, etc.

observer.ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip
Array: True

IP addresses of the observer.

observer.mac.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

MAC addresses of the observer.
The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

observer.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Custom name of the observer.
This is a name that can be given to an observer. This can be helpful for example if multiple firewalls of the same model are used in an organization.
If no custom name is needed, the field can be left empty.

observer.os.family.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

observer.os.full.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Operating system name, including the version or code name.

observer.os.kernel.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

observer.os.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Operating system name, without the version.

observer.os.platform.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

observer.os.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Use the `os.type` field to categorize the operating system into one of the broad commercial families.
If the OS you're dealing with is not listed as an expected value, the field should not be populated. Please let us know by opening an issue with ECS, to propose its addition.

observer.os.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Operating system version as a raw string.

observer.product.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The product name of the observer.

observer.serial_number.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Observer serial number.

observer.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The type of the observer the data is coming from.
There is no predefined list of observer types. Some examples are `forwarder`, `firewall`, `ids`, `ips`, `proxy`, `poller`, `sensor`, `APM server`.

observer.vendor.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Vendor name of the observer.

observer.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Observer version.

orchestrator.api_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

API version being used to carry out the action

orchestrator.cluster.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Unique ID of the cluster.

orchestrator.cluster.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Name of the cluster.

orchestrator.cluster.url.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

URL of the API used to manage the cluster.

orchestrator.cluster.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The version of the cluster.

orchestrator.namespace.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Namespace in which the action is taking place.

orchestrator.organization.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Organization affected by the event (for multi-tenant orchestrator setups).

orchestrator.resource.annotation.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

The list of annotations added to the resource.

orchestrator.resource.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Unique ID of the resource being acted upon.

orchestrator.resource.ip.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: ip
Array: True

IP address assigned to the resource associated with the event being observed. In the case of a Kubernetes Pod, this array would contain only one element: the IP of the Pod (as opposed to the Node on which the Pod is running).

orchestrator.resource.label.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

The list of labels added to the resource.

orchestrator.resource.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Name of the resource being acted upon.

orchestrator.resource.parent.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Type or kind of the parent resource associated with the event being observed. In Kubernetes, this will be the name of a built-in workload resource (e.g., Deployment, StatefulSet, DaemonSet).

orchestrator.resource.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Type of resource being acted upon.

orchestrator.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Orchestrator cluster type (e.g. kubernetes, nomad or cloudfoundry).

organization.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Unique identifier for the organization.

organization.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Organization name.

package.architecture.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Package architecture.

package.build_version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Additional information about the build version of the installed package.
For example use the commit SHA of a non-released package.

package.checksum.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Checksum of the installed package for verification.

package.description.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Description of the package.

package.install_scope.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Indicating how the package was installed, e.g. user-local, global.

package.installed.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

Time when package was installed.

package.license.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

License under which the package was released.
Use a short name, e.g. the license identifier from SPDX License List where possible (https://spdx.org/licenses/).

package.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Package name

package.path.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Path where the package is installed.

package.reference.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Home page or reference URL of the software in this package, if available.

package.size.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Package size in bytes.

package.type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Type of package.
This should contain the package file type, rather than the package manager name. Examples: rpm, dpkg, brew, npm, gem, nupkg, jar.

package.version.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Package version

process.args.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

Array of process arguments, starting with the absolute path to the executable.
May be filtered to protect sensitive information.

process.args_count.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Length of the process.args array.
This field can be useful for querying or performing bucket analysis on how many arguments were provided to start a process. More arguments may be an indication of suspicious activity.

process.code_signature.digest_algorithm.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The hashing algorithm used to sign the process.
This value can distinguish signatures when a file is signed multiple times by the same signer but with a different digest algorithm.

process.code_signature.exists.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

process.code_signature.signing_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

process.code_signature.status.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

process.code_signature.subject_name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Subject name of the code signer

process.code_signature.team_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

process.code_signature.timestamp.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

Date and time when the code signature was generated and signed.

process.code_signature.trusted.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

process.code_signature.valid.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

process.command_line.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: wildcard
Array: False

Full command line that started the process, including the absolute path to the executable, and all arguments.
Some arguments may be filtered to protect sensitive information.

process.elf.architecture.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Machine architecture of the ELF file.

process.elf.byte_order.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Byte sequence of ELF file.

process.elf.cpu_type.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

CPU type of the ELF file.

process.elf.creation_date.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: date
Array: False

Extracted when possible from the file's metadata. Indicates when it was built or compiled. It can also be faked by malware creators.

process.elf.exports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object
Array: True

List of exported element names and types.

process.elf.go_import_hash.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

A hash of the Go language imports in an ELF file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available [here](https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma).

process.elf.go_imports.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: object
Array: False

List of imported Go language element names and types.

process.elf.go_imports_names_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

process.elf.go_imports_names_var_entropy.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: long
Array: False

Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

process.elf.go_stripped.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

Set to true if the file is a Go executable that has had its symbols stripped or obfuscated and false if an unobfuscated Go executable.

process.entry_leader.same_as_process.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

This boolean is used to identify if a leader process is the same as the top level process.
For example, if `process.group_leader.same_as_process = true`, it means the process event in question is the leader of its process group. Details under `process.*` like `pid` would be the same under `process.group_leader.*` The same applies for both `process.session_leader` and `process.entry_leader`.
This field exists to the benefit of EQL and other rule engines since it's not possible to compare equality between two fields in a single document. e.g `process.entity_id` = `process.group_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the process group leader) OR `process.entity_id` = `process.entry_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the entry session leader)
Instead these rules could be written like: `process.group_leader.same_as_process: true` OR `process.entry_leader.same_as_process: true`
Note: This field is only set on `process.entry_leader`, `process.session_leader` and `process.group_leader`.

offset.description:
Module: ecs

text.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: wildcard

Module: ecs

total_bytes_skipped.description:

process.parent.interactive.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

Whether the process is connected to an interactive shell.
Process interactivity is inferred from the processes file descriptors. If the character device for the controlling tty is the same as stdin and stderr for the process, the process is considered interactive.
Note: A non-interactive process can belong to an interactive session and is simply one that does not have open file descriptors reading the controlling TTY on FD 0 (stdin) or writing to the controlling TTY on FD 2 (stderr). A backgrounded process is still considered interactive if stdin and stderr are connected to the controlling TTY.

process.session_leader.interactive.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

Whether the process is connected to an interactive shell.
Process interactivity is inferred from the processes file descriptors. If the character device for the controlling tty is the same as stdin and stderr for the process, the process is considered interactive.
Note: A non-interactive process can belong to an interactive session and is simply one that does not have open file descriptors reading the controlling TTY on FD 0 (stdin) or writing to the controlling TTY on FD 2 (stderr). A backgrounded process is still considered interactive if stdin and stderr are connected to the controlling TTY.

process.session_leader.same_as_process.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: boolean
Array: False

This boolean is used to identify if a leader process is the same as the top level process.
For example, if `process.group_leader.same_as_process = true`, it means the process event in question is the leader of its process group. Details under `process.*` like `pid` would be the same under `process.group_leader.*` The same applies for both `process.session_leader` and `process.entry_leader`.
This field exists to the benefit of EQL and other rule engines since it's not possible to compare equality between two fields in a single document. e.g `process.entity_id` = `process.group_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the process group leader) OR `process.entity_id` = `process.entry_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the entry session leader)
Instead these rules could be written like: `process.group_leader.same_as_process: true` OR `process.entry_leader.same_as_process: true`
Note: This field is only set on `process.entry_leader`, `process.session_leader` and `process.group_leader`.

server.registered_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The highest registered server domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

server.subdomain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The subdomain portion of a fully qualified domain name includes all of the names except the host name under the registered_domain.  In a partially qualified domain, or if the the qualification level of the full name cannot be determined, subdomain contains all of the names below the registered domain.
For example the subdomain portion of "www.east.mydomain.co.uk" is "east". If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.

server.top_level_domain.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

Module: ecs

Array: False

Address where data about this service was collected from.
This should be a URI, network address (ipv4:port or [ipv6]:port) or a resource path (sockets).

service.environment.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Identifies the environment where the service is running.
If the same service runs in different environments (production, staging, QA, development, etc.), the environment can identify other instances of the same service. Can also group services and applications from the same environment.

service.ephemeral_id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Ephemeral identifier of this service (if one exists).
This id normally changes across restarts, but `service.id` does not.

service.id.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Unique identifier of the running service. If the service is comprised of many nodes, the `service.id` should be the same for all nodes.
This id should uniquely identify the service. This makes it possible to correlate logs and metrics for one specific service, no matter which particular node emitted the event.
Note that if you need to see the events from one specific host of the service, you should filter on that `host.name` or `host.id` instead.

service.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Name of the service data is collected from.
The name of the service is normally user given. This allows for distributed services that run on multiple hosts to correlate the related instances based on the name.
In the case of Elasticsearch the `service.name` could contain the cluster name. For Beats the `service.name` is by default a copy of the `service.type` field if no name is specified.

service.node.name.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Name of a service node.
This allows for two nodes of the same service running on the same host to be differentiated. Therefore, `service.node.name` should typically be unique across nodes of a given service.
In the case of Elasticsearch, the `service.node.name` could contain the unique node name within the Elasticsearch cluster. In cases where the service doesn't have the concept of a node name, the host name or container name can be used to distinguish running instances that make up this service. If those do not provide uniqueness (e.g. multiple instances of the service running on the same host) - the node name can be manually set.

service.node.role.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Deprecated for removal in next major version release. This field will be superseded by `node.roles`.
Role of a service node.
This allows for distinction between different running roles of the same service.
In the case of Kibana, the `service.node.role` could be `ui` or `background_tasks`.
In the case of Elasticsearch, the `service.node.role` could be `master` or `data`.
Other services could use this to distinguish between a `web` and `worker` role running as part of the service.

service.node.roles.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: True

Roles of a service node.
This allows for distinction between different running roles of the same service.
In the case of Kibana, the `service.node.role` could be `ui` or `background_tasks` or both.
In the case of Elasticsearch, the `service.node.role` could be `master` or `data` or both.
Other services could use this to distinguish between a `web` and `worker` role running as part of the service.

service.origin.address.description:
Module: ecs
IndexerType: keyword
Array: False

Address where data about this service was collected from.
This should be a URI, network address (ipv4:port or [ipv6]:port) or a resource path (sockets).

Array: False

Identifies the environment where the service is running.
If the same service runs in different environments (production, staging, QA, development, etc.), the environment can identify other instances of the same service. Can also group services and applications from the same environment.

Array: False

Ephemeral identifier of this service (if one exists).
